reviewText: It seems more and more manufacturers are offering so-called tool kits that are designed for small places such as kitchen drawers and glove boxes of automobiles. Most of them are cheaply made, overpriced, and really not worth the buyers time or money. I place this "tool" in that catagory for a number of reasons.For instance, the tool is heavy, weighing in at almost 1 1/4 pounds. It is also a bit bulky and overall definately not something you would drop or throw into a drawer, etc.While there are a total of 7 bits included there is only storage for 6 which means one is always one remaining in the socket. In addition, the holder for the 6 bits has a plastic cover that seems to be of questionable strength and will, I suspect, either break or expand over time and that will be a real problem.The flexible extension for the bit socket (screwdriver) does not have any type of attachment to the main tool and thus helps defeat the purpose of an all-in-one tool. I suspect this potentially handy part will have a tendency to get lost over time.As for the knife attachment I was less than impressed. You need to remove a cover on the tool and then extend the blade to use this one. After doing that you are presented with a cheap looking blade that will be OK if doing easy type work but will not be of much use under average to above average use.I think the idea behind this tool, as with many of the others, is good. However, it seems the manufacturers cannot bring together quality with size (smaller) and end us, as in this case, with a so-called tool that is costly and not well made. It will work, for awhile, for small, light duty jobs but even then I would not expect a long life for this one.
There was nothing in this kit that allowed me to lign up my cabinet door knobs to the bottom corner, where knobs normally go.  The drawer pull stencil worked well.
summary: works for pulls but not so well for knobs

reviewText: I bought this because I have a mysterious draft in my dayroom (lots of windows).  I was able to isolate several potential sources thanks to this little gadget.  Very easy to use, and does exactly what you would want it to do.

many attachments have fussy RPM requirements. This variable speed is not a "step" increments which is great. I love this unit. Fast and powerful. BUT (and this is a biggie) this tool,and all Dremels, are not designed for serious jobs like cutting steel. This is a fantastic hobby tool for crafts and hobbies. If you're restoring a motorcycle or car, this tool has it's place in tiny details but you'll still need an angle grinder, buffing wheel etc. This does not replace any of the bigger tools. It's still a small high speed hand drill for small projects. Some people disagree with me but I've spent hundreds and hundreds of dollars trying nearly every accessory and there are some Dremel tips I think are total junk (IE The EZ lock system that just breaks up instantly, or the metal cutoff discs that cost $25 a pack!!) All in all though I can't live without this unique small tool for what it does.

I bought this jigsaw on a salesperson's recommendation from a home center last summer. The underpowered scroll saw I was using to teach a woodworking class at 4H youth summer camp was not cutting it (no pun intended). I needed a reliable tool with backbone, and fast. It saved the week at camp with flying colors, and showed me just how great Bosch tools really are. Now, I own several Bosch power tools, and not one has disappointed me yet. The orbital action on the Progressor makes it mow right through plywood and studs like nothing. The variable speed knob lets you match the speed to the work. It cuts sheet metal well, too, if you clamp the sheet down on plywood first. I've used the saw to do demolition work, like cutting out plumbing and furnace vent openings in wall sill plates, and cutting access holes into a shingled roof. It's great for cutting PVC and copper pipe, too. This little powerhouse will cut anything with the proper blade. Just insert the blade, and turn the top knob until you hear and feel that CLICK, and you're ready to go. I wouldn't start a remodeling job without it.

Once upon a time Snap-On was an outstanding manufacturer. Those days are apparently gone. This utility knife is a basic run-of-the-mill utility knife. It is neither exceptional nor does it have major faults. It is just an average and somewhat ugly and clumsy utility knife. There is a button located near the front of the knife that can be pushed to close and open the knife blade holder. There is another button on the front of the blade holder that can be pushed to replace the blade. Changing the blade with this Snap-on is a two hand operation and easier to do then with, for aeample, the Stanley utility knife. You can hold this Snap-On knife in one hand and also use that same hand to push the release button while using the other hand to change the blade. With the Stanley you hold the knife in one hand, pull up the latch with your second hand and then you are required to use your third hand to change the blade. The Stanley has a better appearance but probably few utility knife users consider appearance a major factor when making a knife purchase.Although this knife is utile I would not have purchased it if I had known it was made in China or Taiwan. The packaging says Taiwan and the knife says China. Because we are in such serious need of jobs here in the USA I try to do my part by buying USA made products whenever possible.

A right-angle drill/driver is hard to do without. Goodness knows how many times we all have reached into tight places to drive screws manually with ratchets or short screwdrivers. Not fun, is it? The Bosch PS10-2 gets into those tight areas for tasks like attaching drawer slides. Plus, it is reasonably small and light, so you will grab it for a lot of normal drilling and screw-driving tasks. The angle-head feature works perfectly and while 0 and 90 degree angles are the most used, once in a while another angle is useful.This Bosch uses what they call Clic-Change bits. These are 1/4 inch hex shanks with indentations on them (note that some bits have very small indentations for use in other devices. The ones for use in the Bosch are the bigger ones). They are available in every brand and every manufacturer makes drill/drivers that use these bits. This is not a Bosch exclusive. You pull the collar out, drop the bit in, and it is a quick and secure connection. Much nicer than wrestling with chucks.This is why they call these devices "drivers" instead of "drills". Twist drill bits can't be bigger than the hex shank, so they are limited in size and that makes it less flexible than a dedicated drill. Also, drills spin at high speed, while drivers are designed to operate at lower rpms. Bosch feels the primary use will therefore be to drive screws, and as a nut-driver.You can get spade bits because they have build-in hex shanks. Of course, a 10.8-Volt driver isn't meant to drill huge holes through studs all day, but it does have enough power to actually do that.You will still need to have a conventional drill with a twist chuck to use all the bits you have now and will need for many tasks.The slow-start feature would seem to be more useful on big powerful tools like routers, but you get used to it and can use a light touch when needed. The "clutch" isn't a conventional mechanical one and it takes a little getting used to, but it works.The angle feature is secure, the motor is smooth and powerful and everything seems well built. It is far from tiny, though, surprisingly big. It is not at all like those little electric screwdrivers. This is a full-sized, powerful drill/driver.What would make it better? It would be perfect if it had a a selectable impacting action.

reviewText: RULE # 1: CIRCUIT BREAKER OFF AND PLENTY OF WORK LIGHT.I've used Leviton light switches for 3 decades. They last because Leviton uses the best quality materials. The endurance on this switch is 50,000 cycles minimum. Whenever I'm replacing switches in an old house, I use Leviton. When I needed a 20-Amp, heavy duty, single pole, special purpose switch that would stand out, I went to Leviton. They make hundreds of special purpose switches and outlets in many different colors.There are only 3 terminals on this switch: Line/Supply (HOT), Load (HOT) and ground. If you have a grounded metal box, just connect supply and load and you're set.Leviton provides wiring diagrams for their switches on their website. They also provide live chat.If you are replacing an existing switch, especially in an older house, it's a good idea to check the switch box before you buy a new switch and see how many wires you have available. I've found that it's better to know how and what to do in advance instead of trying to figure it out while wearing a headlamp and listening to someone complain because the lights have been off for an hour.Trying to install a switch with 4 terminals in a box with only two wires might get confusing...and vice versa. That's when you need to call a licensed electrician.Have you ever asked someone to hold a flashlight for you and they pointed it in your eyes instead of where you're working?I love headlamps.

reviewerName: Sir Charles Panther "Life is hard.  It's hard...
reviewText: . . . because when you think pleasing domestic atmosphere enhancement in the form of simulated flame, you think Energizer.  That is, think made in China for Energizer Holdings, Inc.The packaging shows the product well, and the packaging color scheme complements the candle.  I found the package somewhat hard to get into, that is, to find the little dab of perfectly transparent tape to get the thing open.  At least it didn't take hydraulic shears to cut through eighteen inches of industrial clear plastic.  Colored tape, a colored tab or even a tear-away zipper tab would be a great improvement for consumers to breach the package and reach the precious digital candle inside.The candle comes in at 3" in diameter, and 6" high.Note that it takes 4 AA batteries, which are not included.  The FCC compliance notice informs that this Class B digital device could interfere with some domestic radio communications, but I suffered no such problems.The package claims "realistic flicker," and I concur.  It totally fooled both the wife and the kids.  I discerned no heat whatsoever from this product.  The LED bulb is set well below the lip of the candle, so its lighting effect is primarily through diffusion through the wall of the candle.  In a completely dark room this product provides minimal additional light (and a nice orangey circle on the ceiling).Note that this is for indoor use only.  This would not be good for an outdoor altar or cemetery vigil.The product's scent is "honey vanilla," but I'm not quite sure what it is.  Of course, the scent does not fill the room as a real candle would, but the scent diffused in a small room relatively quickly, within about two hours.  It's a subtle scent, not unpleasant, but distinctly synthetic/industrial, a manufactured scent rather than something truly natural.  There does not seem to be any increase in the candle's scent if it is turned on or off.The product comes with a multi-folded user manual in English, French and Spanish.  As small user pamphlets go, this one at least has text that is large enough to be read by a human.  There are even a couple of diagrams, one for the installation of the batteries and the other to explain the two switches on the bottom for the on/off/timer and 4-, 6- and 8-hour settings.I tried all three timer settings, and all were accurate, as far as I could tell (no, I didn't time them out).  The candle knows when to turn itself on as well.  It's got an automatic timer setting which turns the candle on at the same time each day, and delays for your four, six or eight hours.  That's a cool feature.The instructions do specify that it is made from real wax; I read this as an implied warning that it could stain certain surfaces, such as fine wood.  I placed a folded sheet of white paper under it, and after a full week detected no trace of any kind of oil, wax, or any other kind of residue/seepage.Bottom line: If you're going to go with candles, there's nothing like real flame, real action, powerful scent, the real thing.  But if you've got pets, kids, or a domestic situation that doesn't lend itself to the real thing, this is a really good substitute, and totally safe.  The scent could be better, but other than that this is a good simulation of the real thing.

reviewText: I continue to search for the ideal LED GU10 light to replace all the power hungry halogen bulbs in my track lighting.  This a good bulb but it has it's issues that make it still not good enough for me to buy a dozen of them.  First the good: it is bright and the light has a nice warm color.  But, the light distribution is narrow (more like a spot light instead of a flood) and while it is dimmable it doesn't get that dim.  When I turn the dimmer to its lowest setting the halogen bulbs dimly glow but this LED light is still fairly bright.  So, if its narrow light dispersion is not a problem for you and you don't need to dim to a night light  / mood lighting level, this LED GU10 bulb will do the job.
summary: Warm light color but a few issues

reviewText: I really like this guage but it comes with no instructions.  I had to guess how to install battery.  This is a true DIY tool.  If you don't know how to figure things out you're in a mess.  I am one who eschews instructions so I had little problem.  Initially I installed battery upside down and feared it did not work.  I realized my mistake and all turned out well.  I used the device many times already and am happy with the results.  I love digital readouts better than analog as it lowers the odds of making a huge mistake.

I got this for a remodeling project that involved extensive use of construction adhesive.  My hand wasn't up to that much squeezing.  I had several inexpensive Campbell Hausfield pneumatic nailers that worked well, so I took the chance on this caulker.  My primarily criteria was price because i didn't intend to use this much beyond this project.  I was surprised to find out that the product was far more versatile than I imagined.Most of the reviewers seem to be spot on regarding this caulker.  The unit is direct-air driven, so it is very sensitive to air pressure so you will need to regulate this for different products and at different pressures and temperatures.  From my experience (and for my applications), optimal flow through a 1/4" nozzle opening for various products are:  PL construction adhesive - 45psi; 3M fireblock - 15psi; concrete patch -  50psi; 3M paintable silicone - 40psi. (all @ approximately 80degrees F).  In most cases i sought maximum flow rate with control a secondary concern.  If I wanted more precise application with maximum control, I'd back off the pressure considerably - maybe as much as 50%.  At this point I've run several hundred tubes ov various stuff through this gun without a problem.This is a very simple design - direct air flow into tube chamber.  As such there's not much to break if you keep the airlines clean.  For what I needed, it worked great.  I do not use this in caulking applications where tethering would be a problem - e.g., caulking windows while on a ladder, but for applying lots of product quickly, it works well.  One feature that I didn't appreciate until i used it was the convenience of tube replacement.  the segmented barrel screws off and on quickly.  this is essential in a production environment when dealing with quick set-up times (like using construction adhesive to sister joists, etc.)I have had no problem with the trigger as some have mentioned.  I've used this for an hour at a time with no ill effect.  I'll admit that the trigger suffers from poor ergonomics, but given the price i doubt they put a lot of funded research into this product.  It does not come with a pneumatic connector, which is fine for me as I only use Milton A-series quick-release connectors on my pneumatic tools, so different connectors are just wasted on me and end up in a coffee can under a workbench.The biggest concern that I had was that something at this low price would actually work as advertised.  I've found that this product has worked great under continuous use for hours at end with no problem as long as one stays on top of the pressure/temp curve.  I should mention that a balance needs to be established between flow rate and runout after trigger release.  The more viscous products will have greater flow resistance, so if you increase the pressure for optimal flow the residual pressure in the tube after trigger release will produce runout.  This is unavoidable for any caulk gun that doesn't have a trigger release/pressure release system built in, and is not a particular weakness with this product.Entirely satisfied.  Recommended.
summary: works well, inexpensive, what's not to like?

I like the idea of biometric safes, but have always been hesistant of their use.  After trying this one, my mind has been changed.  Setting this up to scan several fingers was quick and easy, the hardest part was finding the button to push behind the battery compartment.  There is also a button combination sequence that can be used if you dont want to use the fingerprint scan or find a need to tell someone how to open it for you instead of opening it yourself.  Of course, there is also a key as the final backup, in case the battery dies or you want an 'override' access to the safe.The safe itself is fairly small, but just the right size for a 'normal' handgun.  This fits my full size 1911 pistol in a paddle holster, with 2 extra magazines, but it takes a bit of thought to get it pointed correctly to fit.  You wont fit a Dirty Harry style .44 Mag or a S&W; 500 with 10" barrel in this, but it will fit what most people have or use.The fingerprint scan is quick and very fast, opening the lid quickly and silently.  This aspect is MUCH nicer than I thought it would be.  The fingerprint biometric access is actually faster than the punch code sequence, as you have to tap a button to activate it, then enter the code and wait a second before it opens.Overall, if you need a secure place to store a handgun, this is a great option.  It has mounting hardware to bolt it down if you wish.  If you dont bolt it down, it will serve to keep kids or unwanted 'snooping' but it wont keep anyone from just carrying the whole safe away and opeing it later.
This has added the extra security needed in our house. It was easy to install, easy to program and provides that extra safe place for valuables.

This works, but it eats batteries and it is not that bright.  These days various LED versions have become available. Check those out first.

Negatives: Cost, although G4 halogens are likewise expensive these are still more costly at least initially.Size, because of the components mounted on the backside the light doesn't mount flush in the fixture (under cabinet puck type).Unknown:  Longevity, haven't owned it long enough to know if it will last as long as claimed or that the light output wont diminish (I've read thatoccurs with some LED's).Positives: Similar light output to a 10W halogen which surprised me.Very little, if any, heat.Realistically they may never pay for themselves however if they last the convenience of not replacing the halogens will make them easily worthwhile and as a previous reviewer stated I will replace the other halogens over time to spread the cost. All said, recommended.Now a caveat, bought three one has failed after five weeks. Based on that performance I'm now disappointed and question the idea of replacing the rest of the halogens. If possible I would now lower my rating perhaps to two stars.Update to 11/19/11: The light that failed may have been a fixture problem as I have found that just a small amount of looseness may create a weak connection which can account for flicker or apparent failure. I have since purchased several more and they all work fine, back to five stars.

This is a really nice knife for the money. The shape and size of it make if perfect for an EDC knife. It is solid, came sharp and it opens quick. After a little break in and lubing it with CLP, with a flip of the thumb this knife opens as quick as my SOG Flash assisted opening knife. I love the little mushroom shaped thumb studs. If I had one criticism, it's that when the knife is closed, the end of the spine near the pivot has a little bit of a sharp corner that sticks up. This could be easily reshaped and it would not affect the lockup in the slightest, but it would remove the coating that comes on the blade. I really don't think it's worth modifying but it would be nice if it came with a more rounded edge there. But again, for the price, this knife really is great. I'm seriously thinking of buying another just because I like this one so much.
I have not used this yet but all appears normal. This brand seems well made and should work well.No worries.

This is a great innovation.  I was going to add some more lighting to my shop in areas where I don't work very often but ran across  a review of this light in a wwing magazine.  This gives me the light I need and also a light for a lot of other uses.  Nice to have the plug in for a power tool also.
Very well made.  Have some real heft to them.  Use  standard replacement bulbs which range from 20 to 55 watts.  I use a pair to light my driveway gate at night for the security cameras.

Cut very accurate and square (though I weekly check squareness.)I used it to build a large set of cabinets. I bought a Forrest miter master, which is better than the stock blade. (Which isn't bad.)95% of my face frames and doors were within 1mm of square.Pros:Heavy, great for a fixed setup. Stiff.Fence is perfectly colinearBasically 0 runout with my forest blade.Cuts those 12" panels like a breeze.Cons:Heavy, a pain to move.Tilt tightening screw is a bit cheesy. This faucet with its chrome finish and single-lever control has an elegant and timeless look to it.  As such, it will complement almost any kitchen--from the 1950's kitchen that we have to the more modern granite-filled kitchens in vogue today.  And the spot resistant finish really does work.  Meaning that I expect it will be easy to keep the faucet looking good.  The installation is easy; the instruction manual with its detailed pictures is quite helpful.  And the side spray means that you can conveniently fill the coffee pot or kettle without getting water all over the place.  It also means that you don't need to empty the sink before you can fill a tall container.  And, of course, the side spray is excellent when it comes to cleaning up the mess in the sink.  All, in all, this is a great faucet.

While this won't take the place of your EDC flashlight, this "flantern" is nice to have in a pinch. It can function as a flashlight, but it's very bulky for that purpose. Using it as a lantern is your best course of action. You just flip the top LEDs into the reflector below and you're set. It has a metal ring on the bottom so you can hang it up somewhere, and a wrist strap at the top if you just want to carry it. For its size, it gives off a very nice amount of light. It's not my first choice when I go outside, but if I were in a "lights out" situation this would be very handy.
It works, but the buttons and print are too small and the sound it makes when you hit your torque target is too soft. Good idea, meh execution.

reviewText: I'm not going write a book, I'll just say that these bits have been what I expected. They are high quality and cut very well.  The assortment is a great start for folks w/o a ton of bits.  The 1/2" size does seem to make them beefier.  These bits really make it easy to do a great job on projects. I do a little bit of household woodworking and repairs from time to time and I have a modest tool collection to aid with the tasks. Recently, the need came up to sand and redecorate the trim on the external side of the front door. It was a couple-day job and the most difficult part was the sanding. I was going to sand it by hand, but my wife convinced me to get a power sander. I found this Ridgid 1/4 sheet model. I'd never heard of the brand, but it was fairly inexpensive and looked like it might get the job done.The Ridgid Sander worked well, and greatly aided me in the task. It wasn't a very demanding task, I'll admit. I'll now put the sander away and, perhaps, several years in the future I'll bring it out for some other minor job. It suited my needs well.Gary Peterson

The RCA nightlight charger is a clever idea poorly implemented.  We have 4 cell phone users in the house who are always vying for outlets at night.  I also have a handful of nightlights around to prevent midnight injuries ;)  I like the idea of a combination unit!  It solves a problem (in that I do not have to unplug one or more nightlight so all of us can charge our phones), HOWEVER it is a very bright and harsh light, and not particularly attractive, or subtle (i.e., Some of the nightlights we have more or less "disappear" during the day).  This one looks like it should be in a warehouse, or on a runway.  The light is more or less par with that: very very bright.  We put it in a bathroom where we could close the door so we do not have to see the light, but it is a very harsh light to wake up to!On the positive side, it charges very fast, has a light sensor, and uses one outlet for 2 purposes.On the negative side, it is not shielded (neither electric surge nor usb /line noise) and so can easily fry your phone if there is a surge (we have them almost daily, most do not, so consider the risk for your particular situation).The light is very very bright, like a beacon or reading light more than a night light.The unit is not very attractive, nor is it a slimline, or a neutral color which will be unnoticeable like, for exampleFeit Electric NL1/LED Eternalite LED Auto Sensor Night LightorLeviton 48561-2W .5 W, 120 V, Automatic On/Off LED, Night Light with Etched Shade, 2-Pack, White.The 2 biggest issues for me are not what it looks like, but that it is a very harsh very bright light for a night light, and more significantly does not have shielding to protect your phone (or tablet...) from power surges.  If blackouts/ surges are not much of an issue for you, this is somewhat less important. (Our power fluctuates significantly daily, and I have had a number of losses as a result.  Anything electronic that we own must be plugged into a shielded outlet, with a surge protector or battery back up).I like the idea, and it could have been a problem solver for us.  It has features I look for, like a solar sensor, and uses one outlet for things we routinely use and otherwise would use 2 outlets for.  However is is not particularly good at either of it's functions.  It is too bright for a night light and too industrial and otherwise obtrusive (not slimline, or a neutral color) to blend into most home decor.  It does not have a surge or line noise suppressor which for me is a BIG con.  For those with more reliable power it may not be as big of an issue.  It does, however, take only 1 surge to destroy sensitive electronics.  i wish they had put a surge protector or noise filter on this so i could sleep better at night (providing the glare form the light didn't keep me up) ;)
summary: A clever design, but harsh "industrial" lighting

This is my first utility vacuum, and it fits my needs based on price and performance.The small unit is nice for my garage. While wheels would have been nice, the small unit is better since I can easily store it in the box in came in and put it away in a shelf. There are grooves at the top of the unit that allow you to store the vacuum attachments, but I only use them when actively vacuuming. I remove them and place them randomly in the box when I'm done. The unit also has a place to store the hose, but since I like having everything in the original box, the hose doesn't fit there.In terms of power, the vacuum sucks any debris that is loose. I use it to clean my car and the grooves in the garage floor. Almost everything is easy to suck up. The only problem it has is hair from humans or pets. If the hair gets intertwined with the fibers from floor mats or upholstery, the hair tends to get stuck unless manually removed by hand. This is my only reason for knocking off one star from the review.The power card is ok, but I end up storing an 8 ft extension cord with the unit so I don't have to unplug it while going around the car.Overall, a good vacuum that made cleaning up the garage and car a lot easier.
summary: Good for garage; has difficulty with hair on upholstery

reviewText: Useful item, it snaps on tight, but be aware that light is directed out in all directions -- including right in your face. If you crank up your Fenix, you'll light up the space, but also lose some acuity because of the high contrast between the light and your subject. The Bora 50 inch clamp is an aluminum straight-edge clamp that helps guide your power tool.The most important thing a straight-edge clamp should be is straight, and the Bora qualifies.  I checked it against a trusted 48 inch level and was satisfied with the results.  Where the Bora disappoints, however, is when side pressure is applied.  With it clamped across a 4 foot piece of plywood, I can deflect the mid-point of the clamp 50 thousandths of an inch with firm pressure from my index finger. (Yes, I actually set up a dial indicator for this test).  That's almost 1/16 of an inch deflection.In the real world, if you don't apply undue sideways force as you make a cut, you'll get cuts that are straight enough for most applications.  If you want absolute precision and cabinet-grade final cuts, then this inexpensive clamp is not the best choice.It is much better suited to breaking down full sheets of plywood for easy transport.The clamping mechanism requires the user to operate it from both ends which can be a little inconvenient when dealing with wide workpieces.  The large locking handle is comfortable and makes locking the clamp easy.  But the width adjustment is at the other end of the clamp, which is potentially 50 inches away from the handle.  This isn't as big a problem as it sounds.  With a little practice, you can develop a two step process of hooking the unlocked clamp over the far end of the work and pulling the clamp until it drops onto the wood.  Retrieve the clamp to lock the opposite end and then reapply the clamp and lock it.If I was doing hundreds of cuts a day, that would drive me crazy but for breaking down one or two sheets of ply, it's doable.The Bora clamp is worth owning, but don't expect it to take the place of a $600 Precision Track Saw.Mike

I have owned two pairs of these and love them.  Great eye protection.  Very well made, durable construction, but they do fog up rather easily.  I've had that problem with plenty of pairs of eyewear that cost a lot more.  For the price these are really nice.  I would definitely purchase them again if I needed another pair.

Although I've not install this transformer at this writing, I've opened the package and read the manual. The unit appears to be sturdy and well-built. Most of my lights to be connected are LED and should not add up to anywhere near the capactiy of this transforner, but I did want one that could handle whatever else I intend to connect in the future. There will be a combination of assorted lights including a gas lamp post being converted to low voltage, concrete pagoda, rock lights, solar pagodas converted to low voltage, etc. The area being covered includes front, back and side yards. This project has been in the planning stages for over a year mainly due to locating the appropriate fixtures to create the look I wanted. The gas lamp post is being converted from natural gas to low voltage using a kit, but not all of the inclusive parts because I'm integrating with the rest of the lighting. The solar pagodas are being converted by extracting parts from available LED fixtures and retrofitting into the pagodas. Had intended to purchase "ready-to-go" fixtures, but these just aren't available anywhere. The lighting is primarily intended to highlight various landscape features such as several fountains, birdhouses, etc. along with pathlights. The entire system will be controlled by this transformer with the optional photocell. I'm a hardcore DIY person and not timid in experimenting or doing what had not been done before.Intermatic ML300RTW Malibu 300-Watt Power Pack with Timer and Ground Shield

Ratchets aren't a necessity, but they are certainly nice to have and they make certain tasks much simpler. The KR Tools Pro Series Flex Stubby Ratchet is useful for most ordinary needs and it does make basic repairs easier.  Not only do you get two different ratchet sizes with this device, you also get a flexible head. This feature is nice because it makes the process more comfortable. If you need to tighten/loosen a nut that is lower to the ground, for example, you can bend the flexible head to produce an angle that is just right for optimal comfort. There is no special manuever necessary to move the head or special button to push. You just grab it and bend it the way you like. This feature alone will likely make this ratchet worthwhile for some individuals. It all depends on what projects/repairs you have and how difficult it is to attach the ratchet and start turning.The KR Tools Pro Series Flex Stubby Ratchet is a useful tool, but is does have one potential problem and that is the size. The total length of this ratchet is about six and one half inches, but the handle, while easy to grip, is only about four inches in length. This could present a problem for those with larger hands. Small to medium size hands will not have any issues, but larger hands will have difficulty gripping the handle properly. Another couple of inches of length would solve this problem.Aside from the short handle, however, I like the KR Tools 40215 Pro Series  inch by 3/8 inch Flex Stubby Ratchet and find it very useful for the occasional repair. It turns easily, tightens very well, and offers a flexible head and two ratchets. It could benefit from a larger handle, but it has many positive qualities and it makes a good choice for your everyday tooling needs.
summary: A Useful Tool for Basic Ratcheting Needs

reviewText: Bought this to help when I was buying loose diamonds overseas.  It still rings off on the fakes.  Moissonite is a popular synthetic gem that is presented as a diamond.  Moissonite will register on this diamond tester, but when taken to a gemologist, it's discovered as fake.  There is one tester similar that is $400+, and I've seen that work.  That is hands down the ideal tester.  Don't waste time on a cheap tester like this one.gave it 2 stars only because it does work.  It just doesn't work well enough to keep you from getting taken on a fake.

I read other reviews about this product and I have to say for the price I was willing to take the chance. Firstly my head must be enormous because I had no trouble with the fit. Second it functions just as seller stated but was shipped without batteries.(Sell site stated it did) Third and last of all this product is plenty comfortable for most who use occasionally.  If I were a pro I would surely buy a heavy duty repairable version but these are just fine.

I was curious as to how easy this lock would be to install and operate. I am pretty good at DIY stuff, so I wasn't worried about the install, but wanted to make sure that almost anybody would be able to install the lock. Sure enough, the install is smooth, and they made reversing the levers quite easy as well. The alarm is fairly simple, and is built right into the door knob. I usually use Amazon reviews to judge product quality.  I usually discount a few outliers as you can never satisfy everybody and there is always somebody in every crowd who will gripe and complain about anything and everything.  But, I am utterly astounded that this product had a 4 star rating at the time that I write this.  Just walk into Home Depot and ask for "HDX 16 ft. x 1-1/4 in. Ratchet Tie-Downs" and you will get a much heavier duty and higher quality product for about the same price (I paid $18 at the time I ordered these w/ free shipping) .  I do property management and maintenance and depend on having high quality tie downs for transporting whatever comes up in daily operations.  I do not expect this product to hold up under extreme use.  To be honest, looking at the product quality, I would expect to find these in a harbor freight for a couple of $.  They do not deserve the price that is being charged.  If you pay more than $5 for these I believe you have been robbed...

This "Zip-It" drain cleaning tool is a must have with a teenage daughter with long hair in the house. We get a good clog in the kid's bathroom sink once or twice a year and this handy tool has not let us down yet to clear them out (we bought three of these).Using them is a easy as removing the sink stopper, running the "Zip-It" down the drain, giving it a good twist, and pulling it back out. The gunk that comes up is often not very pleasant to look at but it does clear the drain.Recommended!CFH
summary: Works Well, Easy To Use - Recommended

reviewText: Bottom line: these bungees are high quality and not some cheap knock-off.  I will buy more in the future- without a doubt.

The product works. I used this in conjunction with PEX and associated connectors and it worked just fine. Thiis seems like a very well made, ableit simple, tool and should last years. I have no leaks, which means I did something right.

It's all metal and a real nice tool when trying to weld right angles.  Good for wood working too, but keep in mind, its all metal, so yo may want to put some type of fiber clothe over it if  doing finish work so you don't mar the wood.

You have to admit, the idea of turning a device on / off from your smartphone - even when you aren't anywhere near home is pretty cool. Add to that the ability to trigger that device with a motion sensing control. I have a nice stand up lamp in my home office and every morning I walk in and turn it on and at night I always forget to turn it off. So I placed a motion trigger inside the door and told it to activate the lamp's wemo's. Then, if I forget to turn the lamp off, I can have to turn off at a preset time or just turn it off from my phone.Life saving? No... but very cool. I'd see this as being very useful for outdoor lighting, etc. but I don't have anything like that (yet).

Not bad for a $20 penlight. Go buy one. The Stylus Pro has been a staple of the flashlight community since it came out. Streamlight has updated the Stylus Pro, and it's a good thing...The Stylus Pro weighs just 1.7 ounce with the batteries installed. It's 5-3/8" long and just over 1/2" in diameter. That's pretty compact. The entire light is Type II anodized, and resists scratches nicely for such an inexpensive light. The blue color has a subtle "rainbow" effect with the machining lines showing, and I like it. The Stylus Pro uses a Cree XP-C emitter, but Streamlight calls it their "C4" LED. This emitter, coupled with the smooth reflector, give the Stylus Pro a nice, tight hot spot. It also introduces some visible rings, but they're negligible in real-world use. Output is double the old version of the Stylus Pro - 48 lumens. The lens is clear polycarbonate (plastic) and does its job. I have found that if you use the Stylus Pro around moisture, the water vapors can get between the lens and reflector, condensing the lens without a way to remove it. The light comes with two Energizer AAA batteries, and you should be able to get around 8 hours from a set.The tailcap screws on, and all four of mine came very dry and gritty. After some Tuff Glide, they feel much better. The pocket clip is mounted to the tailcap and can be removed. It's a bit too tight, as you'll have to be careful when screwing the tailcap on so you don't cross the threads. The clip is black, regardless of what color LED or body you choose. The light turns on via forward clicky switch. I like it, although some people have complained that the switch is too hard to press. The switch cover is replaceable by just unscrewing the top portion of the tailcap, and one spare switch cover is provided.  Also provided is a black nylon holster. It works just fine; light goes in, light goes out. It can fit a belt up to 1-3/4" wide.I like the Stylus Pro in general. It's a good light. I have noticed that the new C4 versions have had more problems with cross-threading, but Streamlight has excellent Customer Service if you should have that problem. I think the Stylus Pro would make an excellent EDC light, or part of a kit.

I've only used this ladder once, but it works well and seems to be solidly built.  As other reviewers have commented, it is quite heavy.  Perhaps that's unavoidable in a very sturdy piece of equipment.  This ladder has a trait that I was not expecting: there is absolutely no place to set a tool or other item you might be carrying while on the ladder.  Unlike my six-ft Werner ladder, the rungs are not  flat steps but rather round poles.  You can't rest so much as a screwdriver on them. I was installing a security light, so I not only had tools, but the light as well.  I had to jury rig a cardboard-box attachment in order to complete the job.  I've seen after-market attachments for sale, and I'll certainly be getting one.  In my view, the ladder should come with such an attachment -- it's essential.
Tal como se describe, es preciso, práctico y útil en la determinación de temperaturas en cualquier circunstancias de trabajo. Lo recomiendo ampliamente.

This fan is amazing! Installed in a full bath in August 2013 and have loved it from day one. Easy to install and whisper quiet. There is no grinding or gear turning noise. All you hear is the whisper of airflow. Be careful not to leave it on by accident... I have forgotten it was on before because it is THAT quiet!

I actually do not know whether using such product is safe or not !In many case I need an extension so I purchased it but in very high RPM , the question is , dese it well balanced . the router works with sounds in high level so I do not know whether it is normal or not .

The label is slightly misleading when it says "non-programmable" -- it can be programmed for Home-Sleep-Away and those settings must be cleared after installation if you don't want to mess with them. The cool/heat - on/auto settings are slider buttons that one can use a fingernail or thumb to move. My only wish is that these were backlit, too. I know next to nothing about electricity, so I had mine installed by a service tech. I do not recommend trying it yourself unless you know your way around a circuit board and wires. MAKE SURE you set it to fit your system -- Heat Pump or AC/Furnace. Choosing the wrong one will cause it to misread the controls and shut off your heat/AC prematurely. If you're looking for simple and will work forever, this is your thermostat.
summary: A very good, simple, and durable thermostat

reviewText: I have used the gooseneck scraper the most and find that it holds an edge for suite a while and is surprisingly easy to sharpen.  I highly recommend this set!

It's cheap, and it heats. This is not meant to heat a room, it's meant to set on a desk or point directly at you. It's good if you just want to warm yourself and not the entire room or those around you.

These seem sturdy enough.  I had trouble getting the snap rings off using them.  But honestly, I it could have just been my own lack of skill or not really having the proper size.  Because I might not need to use these for the next 5 years, couldn't see spending a bucket load on a set pliers.

I do a lot of work around the house and sometimes you just can't do a job right as you don't have enough hands to hold the work.  Some jobs require you to hold a piece in place for quite a while, like gluing a broken drawer for example.  That is where I love these clamps.I like that the clamps are easy to adjust and have non-marring pads on the surfaces that touch the work.  My last two projects were made so much easier with these clamps.  I have an old desk that belonged to my father and one of the drawers kept coming apart.  A little wood glue and a bar clamp to hold it into place for several hours resulted in perfect fit and strong joints for the repair.I also had to recently extend a door sweep to seal a gap and I was able to add a piece of wood to the bottom of the door with waterproof construction glue and apply pressure until it dried.  A little stain and varnish and you can't even tell that the door was modified.These clamps are easy to use, clamp and also to release.  I own multiple sets and they help complete some tough jobs.  They come with a lifetime warranty.I strongly recommend them to you as useful tools to own!
summary: Just like an extra set of hands!

reviewText: The drill bits seem OK, so far, but the case is a piece of junk!  The second time I tried to open the case it got stuck.  Finally got it opened but the smaller drill bits in back fell out all over the floor as the metal holder they were in was all bent to hell.  Bits get an "A", case gets an "F".

reviewText: this tool box is perfect. there are sections that are easily accessible on top which is a great plus. fits a lot of tools inside and has a nice clean look,

After realizing that I could not use this on my own well supplied water, I installed it on my BFF's city supplied faucet. Nicer than the super cheap ones, but still looks slightly cheezy. The water tastes GREAT! No more chlorine taste. It was easy to install, and not overly bulky.
I installed this little switch along with the Genie Keyless entry system, and both of them work exactly as advertised.  Can't go wrong.

This is well made and about as comfortable as any. The visibility through it is good - when it's not fogging up. Of course it does that at a critical time. For the money it's good for a home workshop where I don't wear it for long periods.
I love this tool. I use it more for drilling holes and installing screws. The tool is perfect for my use.

These finger lights are packaged in packs of 4 and only had a few duds (2 out of 40 were DOA). The lights are very bright and had an impressive life span. Though not durable or particularly well made, they survived the few days of rough play the kids put them through. Will buy again.

reviewText: It was hard to pass up all the deals on the comparable Makita drills but the Amazon negative reviews stayed me away. Not only am I pleased that I waited and got a screaming deal on these Bosch and I have had nothing but great experiences with both tools. Have used them a lot and LOVE the bag they came in as well for it is big enough for me to put my drimmel bag of tools in with the two drills. I read a few reviews here where people complained about not having a hard plastic case. Heck I have been doing carpentry for 35 years and had many of those metal and plastic cases gather dust in my garage.Plus as I am sure you have read already, the batteries are above average also. The only con to the set is the included organizer.  It does not close and does not have actual hinges.  It just has flaps that act as hinges and from experience, those don't last long. Nicely replaced all my incandescent 60 watt light bulbs. According to the GE packaging the new bulbs should save me $$ on my electric bills. I do find it interesting that lifespan is estimated on only 4 hours of usage per day. Oh well as they say only time will tell.I put a date on the base of the lamp. So I will know how long they do last.  The 4 star rating is related only to the length of shipping time,otherwise if would be a rating of 5 stars
summary: GE 26 Watt Energy Smart CFL - 6 Pack - 100 Watt Replacement

reviewText: I've had my old mini mag for several years now and was reluctant to put it aside for the new LED lights that i have accumulated so when i found this upgrade i jumped on it. I'ts a little difficult to install and the on/off switch seems a little loose,that's why the four stars instead of five but i still like. Much easier to move from truck to The new leg closures are a great improvement over previous models.I have table saw w/ the Bosch collapseabile stand w/ wheels, but to move to pick- it takes 2 guys. After way too many years of yanking up my toolbelt way too often, I finally purchased suspenders for them. The suspenders work great, but are on the short side. I'm 5'11" and have the straps maxed out and the suspenders bring the tool belt above my waist - higher than where I usually wear pants/belts, etc. A little uncomfortable at first, but once I realized I made it through a whole day without once hitching up my belt, I knew I would get used to them.The gel pads are comfortable, albeit a little warm. But let's face it, anyone who actually works outside is no stranger to being warm/sweaty/ uncomfortable/overall miserable in the middle of summer.The cell phone pocket - because the suspenders are high - actually ends up very close to the top of my shoulder. Again, it's just a matter of getting used to and as an added bonus the cell phone is closer to my ear and I don't have to fish around for it in my pocket. Ditto for the pencil holders on the opposite strap.

These are comfortable, which is what I was looking for so I would be more likely to wear them.  I haven't had any issues with them fogging up like some other safety glasses.  No complaints, I would buy them again.

This is my first can gun, i know there are other brands out there so i am just gonna judge by this one, i do alot of spraying and anybody that does knows that you have to keep changing fingers all the time, as one finger gets tired i would switch to another and eventually end at the thumb, i have also read reviews and i can safely say it is a sturdy device, it feels a little loose when tilted to the side but most cans cant work sideways anyway, so far i have run 6 cans of primer 8 cans of paint and 3 clear coats, it has worked perfectly and requires little effort, cuts my work in half and no finger pain, just make sure the spray nozzle is facing out, duhh

reviewText: Once you get past the fact that they included a 4 bin box for your 6 different types of blades, this is an impressive set of blades. I found them much stronger than other brands I've tried from Home Depot. Bosch claims 2 sets have been especially prepared for heavy steel, etc. I've tried one set and found them superior to others I've tried --not revolutionary--simply better. These days with all the cheap Chinese blades on the market--I'm glad to have found these.

Since they were offering this little hand tool free with their Orbital Sawzall I figured it was probably junk. The quik-lok job saw is by no means junk.  It is as well made as Milwaukee's Sawzalls and provides as much utility.  The hand saw uses standard reciprocating saw blades and boasts the same tooless blade release mechanism (Quik-Lok) found on the Sawzalls.  I have found the soft grip handle also very comfortable.  I have used this little saw more often than I ever would have thought.  Sometimes a reciprocating saw is overkill and you just want to make a small neat cut in a fragile area.  This tool is often the best choice.  For $20.00 you can't go wrong; obviously it won't replace your reciprocating saw but it certainly will facilitate its use.
summary: Thought it was just a gimmick; I was wrong!!

reviewText: Both the head band and magnifier bill adjustment "wheels" are smooth making it a bit difficult to get adjusted.  The headband was particularly difficult to widen when removing from box. Just the opposite with the magnifier bill, it fights you to stay tight and in place. Once I got used to dealing with these two adjustment issues, the magnifier works great. Hands free magnification when working with small pieces parts is a most as the hands of time march forward.
summary: Adjustments a bit hard to set

reviewText: I started installing a new laminate floor in my home last year and I couldn't believe how much of a headache it was cutting the door jambs so the floor would go under them. I purchased another electric tool for this purpose, the kind that vibrates the blade but this was a total waste. I have solid oak, 120 year wood throughout my home. This is my third Bosch tool and WOW, this really cut the oak  with no problem. The learning curve is minimal with this saw. It features a speed control, light and a no tool needed blade change. Extra blades are available at Amazon also. I used the coarse blade at the fastest setting. The saw is fairly heavy which doesn't make a difference, it's being used at floor level. It's really well made like my other Bosch products. I can't compare it to the other saws that cost several hundred dollars because I haven't used them but I can assure you that buying a cheaper tool is a waste of money. It does the job and is a real bargain for this job. No I don't work for Bosch but I really do appreciate a really well made tool when I find one.
summary: The perfect tool for installing laminate flooring. I can't believe how much time and money I have saved with it.

reviewText: I'm a bit surprised that the clip and ring aren't included with the Waves, but I guess that's the corporate mentality.  These may not be value added for all users and they can turn it into a profit instead of increasing the base price of the multitool.That said, in response to the other reviews, you don't want to oil the blades so they slip open at the slightest movement.  That was the the problem most likely.  The other problem is that the clip isn't meant to have the tool on your belt or exposed.  It's supposed to go inside your pocket where it has a modicum of protection and the clip only allows it to ride at the top.  It's not meant to carry the full weight outside of a pocket or on a belt.  The pocket also provides protection of sorts from the blade opening inadvertantly.I don't use the lanyard ring very often, but when I do, I enjoy the quick release feature.  The ring itself is on the sharp and thin side, so over time, it could wear through a lanyard if you don't use a metal connector and just tie it off.All-in-all, these are a nice compliment to the New Wave, and I recommend them since they aren't that expensive.  They do what they are designed to do - if you buy them knowing that, you'll be satisfied.

These are really great! I haven't used them on metal yet, but they work very well on everything else. Comfortable to use, with a nice action. The only problem is that the lock is on the wrong side (left handed model?).
This sharpener is simply the best sharpener I've ever had!It turns old dull knives I had in my kitchen drawer into useful cooking knives again! Very happy with the quality and the results!

reviewText: I have a couple of impact drivers, and they are older, they are far from ancient, but compared to dewalt, the Greenworks is a monster! The G24 has more torque than you will likely need. I mean, even when testing it out,before I started driving screws, I could feelthe torque and itactually is so strong that I have to figth the rotation. You just have to be careful that youdon't over do it. The drill is a little heavy, heavier than my Dewalt. But comparing the two, GreenWorks is much more powerful. Battery life is good, and it charges normally, not super fast, not super slow. There is a little bit of an odor when you start using it at first, but that goes away. I was not thinkingof starting up my garage project, but guess what.....I did. Sheetrock up, supports and header done. Door put up.Now working on the rafters for some extra storage. Next will be repairing a wall. Sweet! I am very glad I got this. My favorite (for a long time) was my Panasonic, but now I am newborn and a full GreenWorks fan. I like the case it comes with. Keeps it clean, neat and organized. If you are looking for a solid impact drive with lots of torque, look no further! You have found it, sobut it now folks!
Great extension cord. Built very rugged. One of the best cords I have ever owned. Can't say enough good things about it. Highly Recommend.

It's more powerful and cuts smoother than a crappy B&D; full-sized recip saw I got as a gift. Not that that's saying much.Vibration IS pretty crazy at top speed but with this much power and portability, something had to give and it certainly wasn't the quality or construction of the tool. Fortunately it's not a continuous thing. At lower speeds it's quite stable but around 75% on the trigger it starts to shake a bit and I'm not sure I'd feel comfortable using anything but two hands on it at top speed. I don't think I'd like it for repetitive use at top speed for long periods of time, but that's not really the kind of work this tool is meant for.So basically, if you want a finer cut, or decent control when cutting one-handed, you'll have to take it down a notch. If all you care about is making two pieces where there was once one ASAP, however, the option to go full bore is there and it cuts faster than I had hoped at this speed and still smoother than the B&D.; I've used it do a plunge cut through an inch of pine and I'm looking forward to trying out the wood scrolling blades when I get the chance since I can't really afford a jigsaw at the moment and the cuts seem pretty smooth at lower speeds.Which is the only really negative point for me. I like it just a little bit too much to give it up but I didn't really need it. I'm psyched to get that impact driver via the rebate and I love my subcompact drill/driver but as incredibly handy as it will come when I actually do have a use for it, there's other tools that would have been a better choice for me personally. That's more of a knock against me than the tool though and I suspect I'll feel less ambivalent when I start my first rehabbing project.Oh well, at least it replaces that ridiculous B&D; saw, which, incredibly enough, feels like a toy by comparison, both in the hands and during use. I can only imagine how much a corded or V28 sawzall outclasses the B&D.; But then I couldn't just throw one of those into a large inner trench pocket or a glove compartment.Usually people complain that the case didn't leave any room for extras like blades and other stuff. This case is nice and fits everything in the kit along with space to keep a full-sized blade in the tool during storage, a third battery and an extra pocket for more blades. If portability for transport is less of a concern, you'll probably like this case. Personally, I would have opted for one that sacrificed the convenience of not having to detach the blade and less space for extras in order to keep it smaller.Blade-swapping is about as easy as it could be. They pop out with a twist of a knob and pop in with even less effort and none of the uncertainty of a lesser tool. The ability to use full-size blades is nice in a pinch, I suppose, but I stick to the ones designed specifically for this tool as it has a noticeable impact on performance.If you've never encountered a Milwaukee sawzall in real life and it's the portability of this tool that appeals to you, I'd recommend having a look at a sawzall first. The best of the corded sawzalls is cheaper than this kit and they are already surprisingly compact tools for the amazing things they're capable of. If it has to be cordless, check out the V28 (but not the kit - it's priced more than its components cost separately).Overall, I'm very impressed, but let's be honest. If you're not sure you need one of these, you probably don't. If you're a member of any of the obvious professions Milwaukee has targeted with its m12 line, it's definitely worth a look.
summary: Very Well-Made and Powerful for its Size - But Do You Need One?

reviewText: This is by far the best socket kit I have purchased as far as price of the quality. I like Stanley tools. I just wish they were made in America. But I live paycheck to paycheck and I needed new tools and I think I made a wise purchase. They are tough and reliable. I will buy more Stanley tools in the future.
Small, very light weight, and surprisingly bright broad beam for a single AA battery (but not great for distances as a result).  Tremendous value at the price!
An awesome package.  The impact driver packs some punch and is still light and handy too.  The drill is simple and reliable.  The light is a bonus and is bright too.

reviewText: ***Dec 2013 update***Battery charger stopped working. Had to buy a new one. What is it with Dewalt/Bosch/Milwaukee battery chargers??The drill and the original batteries are still working not a hint of any problems.----We put a 6" hole saws on our drills when needed. reviewText: I was skeptical as to how well this could work. Not any more. It is a very cool tool. It's great for quick checking your table or miter saws. It is excellent for use on any surface to quickly check an angle. I can't speak to how accurate it is but so far it definitely is inside of a degree. I didn't get it for precision work. I got it for very quick adjustments. Snap it on to a steel edge and you have a very quick level.It is a little pricier than I was expecting but these days there is a lot of value in saving time. So far it appears to be made very well. It's slightly bigger than you might think but it has a good size display that I haven't had any problem reading indoors or out.

Up to this point in time, I've owned an old utility knife that was my father's - it's made of metal and you have to unscrew screws to open it up to change the blade - and a plastic box cutter that got wet and now has rusted snap blades.  I usually wind up just using a pair of scissors or a kitchen knife when I have to cut something open or score anything.This is a really nice utility knife, really nice.  It's got a rubberized coating which makes is both comfortable to grip and non-slippery.  It's sized so that it fits well in my hand, with curves and grips in the right spots.  The blades are easy to replace - no need to unscrew anything - lol.  The slide switch for the blade is on the left side, and seems to work well for either a right-handed or left-handed person.  It's a bit weighty (especially compared to my plastic box cutter) but the weight is distributed well and I think would actually be useful when used to score something because there would be less chance of wavering.  I've used it to open boxes and cut through plastic packaging with ease.The utility knife also can function as a wire stripper, and the packaging says that it can strip up to 12-gauge wire, not the 10-gauge mentioned in the Amazon description.  There's a notch on the underside that exposes a portion of the blade that allows you to strip wire.  The notch is recessed deep enough that there's no chance of accidentally cutting your finger. Also on the underside there is a storage compartment that flips open to store up to five new blades.  There is a magnet in the slot provided for the blades that holds them tight when the compartment is open, yet they are easy to remove.  The storage compartment opens smoothly and clicks shut.  The packaging states that the utility knife comes with a limited lifetime warranty, but doesn't state what the limitations are.This is a well-designed tool.  It also seems to be well-made.  I happened to get the tool free in order to review it, but it is something that I would actually buy; sure as heck beats my plastic box cutter.  I don't think that the Amazon price is expensive, considering the quality of the product and the likelihood that it will stand up to years of use.  I would recommend it.
These blades work well and were exactly what I needed to cut my laminate flooring.  The price was better than the home improvement stores.

This Sylvania 9-watt LED Reflector lamp is excellent for outdoor use. A nice, bright LED light, it's energy efficient and can be put to good use on the garage or back steps to ward off intruders or to help you navigate the stairs at night without falling and breaking your neck. There are many promises about its longevity and energy savings, but those can only be tested with time. Right now, I'd say it's a good buy.

If you're like most people today, you have a bunch of gadgets that are charged via USB adapters.  Many times you need to plug in a big block transformer into your outlet for each device.  This outlet solves some of this need.  You get the ability to plug in a USB cord directly into the wall and the transformer is built in.  So you avoid the big transformers.PROS- You get direct USB plugs- 2.1 amp means it'll charge most devices including IPAD type devices (the more power hungry ones)CONS- why only 2 USB ports.  I really think this device would be fantastic if it came with 3 or 4 2.1 amp USB ports plus one AC outlet.  That would make this really usable.- You need some experience with electrical wiring to install this item.  It can be dangerous to install this without experience and knowledge of electrical concepts.  You can create a hazard if you don't know what you're doing and you can put yourself in danger if you don't know what you're doing.- Only has 2 USB ports.  Many of us have an Iphone, IPad, a bluetooth headset, and a Kindle....or if you cohabitate, you might have 2 iphones, 2 Ipads, 2 kindles, and 2 bluetooth headsets (8 devices!).  We need more plugs Leviton, great initial offering but we need more juice!OVERALLI like it and it's a useful addition.  If it had 4 ports, it'd be perfect.
if you buy a rotary tool you must purchase this.  pointless to not.  don't ask questions just click purchase right meow.

These filters are the same size as the original Honeywell filter but the original came with a peal and stick foam strip to add to the top of the filter if needed to ensure a good air tight fit. Nordic Pure is the same size as Honeywell but they do not include the foam strip. Not a big problem as I had some foam strip weather seal on hand that I used, but it could be annoying to someone who has to go out to get this. All in all a good filter at a good price, and of course Amazon Prime is the best as is customer service, should you need it.
This is incredible for the price.  It is amazingly bright and the batteries last a very long time.  Very rugged.  You can't buy a better flashlight for the price.

This thing started off fine but has really faded the last few months. It has some great features and I want to give it more stars but the extra features don't make up enough ground. The main issue is the orbital feature, this is very important with precise cuts in hard wood. The orbital on this saw only works some of the time, and there's no way of predicting when it'll stop working, sometimes in the middle of an important cut. Sure, the saw has a toolless plate adjustment, which is a great design element and works pretty well,but who cares if it can't cut a straight line when the orbital cuts out.IMO, it's not a pro quality tool but would be OK for a homeowner who only occasionally needs a jigsaw. Don't use this saw on expensive wood, it'll let you down. If you're looking for a top quality jigsaw go with the Bosch, it's the best.

This is a very good sawblade. I bought it to cut 3/4 inch birch plywood when making kitchen cabinets and I'm very pleased with the cuts - no tear-out on the good side and minimal on the other wide. Would definitely recommend.
summary: Very good blade for 3/4 inch birch ply

reviewText: I bought this pump to replace my old wayne and this one is far superior. Its super fast and very quiet. I put in a new quiet check valve and I can't even here this run unless I'm right beside it. I would highly recommend. (Update) Two years later switch failed

Charges my iPad and phone at the same time.  One USB port Is high output.  The other seems not to be.  This has not proven to be an issue.Installed in kitchen counter outlet to charged devices easily.
I've had this exact same model for over 30 years and it works just fine. I have no reason to find another soldering gun.

These are decent filters for the money. Unfortunately (for me) they decided to make the 12x25x1 filter 11x24x1 which proved to be too small for my unit. I tried shifting it every way possible but the only position it seems to fully cover and not allow dust and debris into the coils is shoved way down. Problem is the filter then gets soaking wet from the condensation channel that runs below it. Shame this company didn't decide to go ahead and make the filter the TRUE size stated on the package. I have no use for these now. Yes, I am blaming the maker for something I knew when I ordered them, but when I really think about it, it is the actual size that should be listed on the package. Not a fictional size.
summary: Good filter, but the SIZE matters

reviewText: This 3M Hard Hat is very comfortable and provides good protection on the job site. There seems to be a lot of confusion about the assembly instructions but I was able to follow them without any real difficulty and had it fully assembled and ready to wear within 5-minutes of opening the package.Once assembled,I found this to be generally equal or even superior to other hard hats that I wore as an installer for a phone company. The "4-Point Ratchet Suspension" is comfortable and easy to adjust and the "UVicator(tm) Sensor" will let you know when the hard hat has reached the end of it's service life (Ultraviolet radiation will weaken the plastic over time). I like the venting on the top as it allows airflow, which is a big improvement over the older designs.Highly Recommended!CFH

I wonder where quality control was when this lamp was packaged, because  my lamp arrived with the cord coming out the top, and not pulled through the pbottom like it should be. In other words, the socket, rather than being attached to top of the lamp body, dangled by a couple of feet of cord, while the cord coming out of the bottom was very short. I tried pulling it through, but that only scaped the cord badly.The other problem was that that the small metal piece on top of the harp, to which you attach the finial was crooked, so that once you attach the shade, it would be slightly crooked,I am planning to contact amazon for a replacement, and if that one works out,i will post an amended review .

I own 4 of these dimmers in both black and white.  Here's what I like about them:1) Great sensitivity in the low light range.  I can dim lamp bulbs so low that I can read the writing on them, then go even lower so that it's almost impossible to see anything in the room other than a faint glowing from the bulb.  This is nice for the times when we're staying up with the baby and only want the least amount of light necessary to avoid bumping into objects after our eyes have adjusted to the darkness.2) No noise.  We have one of these on a bedside table, and it doesn't vibrate or make any other annoying noises.3) Soft green LED when the switch is off.  The LED makes it easier to find the switch, but the green color is dim enough to be discrete and is a pleasing color (at least to me).  When the switch turns on, the green LED goes off.4) Various mounting options.  There is a recessed slot on the back of the switch into which a screw's head can slide for wall mounting.  It comes with removable rubber feet to keep it from sliding off a table top.  With the feet removed, the back side is smooth, so I glued one to the underside of a bedside table's overhang for a discrete yet convenient location.I compared this table top dimmer to the one made by Lutron, and I'm happy I chose the Leviton instead.  Apparently the Lutron doesn't have as much sensitivity in the low range and it has a red LED that I like less than green.I bought mine from big box stores since the were significantly cheaper than the Amazon.com prices.

This is a very handy tool. I use it to set the reveals for trim work. It is small enough to fit in a pocket, bib apron or tool holster. It is very accurate for small measurements, much easier to use than a tape.  Instead of trying to guess the reading of a curved tape while doing an inside measurement just place the tool against the corner and add six inches. It can be used to measure and transfer angles. Checkout the videos on Kregs website for more uses.
Sturdy enough and easy to fix.  What more can I say that hasn't already been said?  Well worth the money.

Not much to say other than I love it. The self centering chuck is great, its built well and works flawlessly. I haven't had trouble with slippage and enjoy turning so much more than I did before. I will order a second one as a matter of fact and would recommend this chuck to others.
summary: Made turning so much more enjoyable.

reviewText: I would buy again. Fit very well. Not too thin and I feel like my hands are protected. I think these are a good value. Saved my knuckles from lots of hurt.

Very easy install, first time install one of these, went well and i like that it has a spring to keep it closed.  The "grille" isn't really firm but doens't need to be, people aren't using it as a life saving device.
